name: 2-fluoro-5-iodopyridine
Reason: The target compound 2-fluoro-5-iodopyridine is based on a pyridine ring, which has a melting point of around -42°C. By introducing functional groups to the pyridine, the melting point can be affected. The fluorine atom has a -I (inductive withdrawing) effect, which generally tends to slightly raise the melting point due to increased polarity and potential for stronger intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. We may estimate this increase to be around +10°C. The iodine atom, being much larger and heavier, has a +I (inductive donating) effect but also significantly increases the molecular weight and size of the molecule, leading to greater London dispersion forces which would substantially raise the melting point. This effect could be estimated to contribute +60°C to the melting point. Therefore, the combined effects of both the fluorine and iodine atoms should raise the melting point of the base pyridine molecule substantially.
